title: Supporting Engineering projects through OpenCourseWare: Two case studies

author: Gijs Houwen, Delft University of Technology (TU Delft)

segmentation: Welcome everyone, my name is guys Howard notoriously difficult to pronounce, but that's OK.
It's a typical Dutch name.
I'm from Delft University of Technology Ann.
I want to share with you today what we did for two engineering projects at our University.
So the title of the talk is supporting engineering projects through open courseware.
This is a really concise overview of what we're going to do today, so the what supporting projects through open courseware.
So what?
Well, I will tell you about how it helped us meet some of open education's challenges that we encounter and you might have similar experiences at your institutions.
How did we meet those challenges by having really targeted and focused?
Open courseware publications.
So the courses we published where in line with the project goals or very closely related to the topic an at the end I'll have some final results and hopefully some time for questions and discussion.
First, a short overview of the open and online portfolio we have at the Delft University of Technology so you can put it in a broader context.
Our core business is, of course, campus education.
We have 19,000 students at the moment.
Bachelors Masters PHD's an we have two blended bachelors.
Open courseware, the main reason why we're all here this this week we have over 130 courses online and we have more than 800 visitors today.
Since September of last year, we already we also started running books on the edx platform.
We did two in September and there's three of those running now.
All in all, we have more than 100 and 25,000 enrollments for those five courses combined.
And we also have online distance education programs that we also started last year.
For the open courseware page, next to the courses that we group on the different study level.
So Masters or bachelors.
We also have some pages that have a specific team so that water help.
Although open courses that we have under those topics, we also group on the page.
We have several research institutes at Delft University of Technology.
For example on energy on the environment an there we use the same principle As for the thematic pages.
We group the courses that relate to the Research Institute on the one page.
But of course we want more, so we also have the Dell DOT NL slash more.
The main things we want to do there and experience with get experience with is to.
Meet some of the challenges that we that we have.
I think we're doing really well at our University and I think we're all very happy with the progress we've made and all this crap going.
But there's always room for more.
There's room for improvement, so we would like to engage Steven students a lot more with our open education activities.
Provide some more focus and impact to the open courseware that we publish.
An also stimulate the use and the reuse of our courses, of course.
For visitors from outside the University, but also for our students for our teaching staff and for particular very focused groups of students.
Then the projects that we combined with last year, the thermal project which is short for that very long sentence.
You see there, it's a real tongue twister.
This year they had a sensor design competition.
The big idea of the Tamil project is to develop low-cost weather stations for Sub Saharan Africa.
They want to have a network of 20,000 weather stations.
But for that you need cheap and innovative sensors because at the moment the weather stations are really expensive.

For that reason, they decided to have a sensor design competition for African universities where they were invited to design new innovative, an low-cost sensor that could be used in the weather stations that they are developing.
And of course, there's a big education component in there.
And we thought it was a really cool idea and a really cool project.
So we started talking with them to combine.
That's the first project, the second project Dot Racing Delft University of Technology Racing is one of a number of racing teams we have at the University.
They built an electric race car and they are currently the world record Holder for fastest acceleration of an electric car.
Also, one of the projects where we thought, well, this is really nice.
This is interesting.
Let's see if we can combine with them.
What's also very interesting is they design a new car each year there's 90 students.
Of course they want to win the competition there in they want to be world Recordholder, but their main focus is education.

They want to educate the students that are in the project an also they want to share their lessons learned and their education with the outside world, which of course aligns very well with our open courseware goals.
So open courseware for the Tamil project.
So in this sense of design competition, it's a combination of hydrology and water management, an of electronics, an measurement technology also in the participants.
For the competition it was seen that they were either from water resources or from electronics and their backgrounds.
So we had a combination of these courses so that the hydrologist could learn about electronics an the other way around.
And we published seven courses for this project.
We managed to do that in about 2 1/2 to three months time, so that is also one of the things that already shows how engaged the staff was that we were working with.
An what you see here is the project page under the Delta, then L slash more.
There's a similar page also at the time or website, so there's also ensures that the people who visit the Tamil website.

Have a different way of accessing the open courseware through that website and the people who visit the Open Courseware website have a different way of accessing the thermal website, so together this reinforces each other.
Well, some of the results for the demo project.
So 7 new courses.
That we found at this step engagement was really high together with the thermal team we started looking at.

Which courses would be valuable for the participants in the design competition we came up with a list an I think out of the 10 courses we had on that list, seven of those we managed to publish as open courseware.
So that's a pretty high success rate.
And even one of the courses was the Bachelor.
Course, Ann.
The professor teaching that he gave me a phone call and he said, well, I really want to help out with the project.
I think it's a really nice idea.
But my courses in Dutch show is that very helpful for their participants.
I said, well, we don't have a lot of Dutch participants, but you know?
I think it's still a great ID and he said well, but why don't I just translate it and then teaches in English and then we can record those video lectures and then over participants can use it.
Well, you know this doesn't happen very often that somebody from the teaching staff calls me an.
Ask me ask me to do some more work for us, but of course I didn't say no.
So he said, well, I talked to my Director of Education, see if I can teach my course in English for my bachelors students.
Well, director of education also agreed he translated this course and now we could use it for all the participants in the design competition.
So it shows how.
Well, if you put a little bit effort in engaging the staff through these projects, our positive responses can be.
We got also feedback from the participants at the end of the giant competition.
They had a workshop in Nairobi where everybody came together an they connected all 21 sensors that they had developed in the competition.
We have some for a bit of feedback an they were really positive.
They requested some additional courses even when they also were able to tell us that it really filled some of the gaps in their knowledge.
They had the knowledge that was necessary to participate.
In the design competition.
Also it shows a link from the theory that we teach in our education to very practical applications in the real world.
I think that's a very nice combination.
Also, since the participants were mostly at African universities at.
Gave us a bit of experience with offline use for open courseware where we found that you know.
We assume that everybody has a really good Internet connection that they can stream the web lectures that we have and all those things.

So we had to put a bit more effort in to make the course materials available offline so that they could be shipped on a USB drive to all the participants, so that's also a very valuable experience for ourselves.
I'm.
This is the thermal website where they also have the course materials listed.
Um?
Anne, this is picture of.

Well, let's not call it a weather station, but these are all the sensors combined from the design competition and they all managed to connect them at the end of their workshop an have it transformed all the data to an online database and we were very happy that we could help help them out in reaching this goal so.
Sing to the dot Racing team and there's a new design every year.
Ann, we started talking with the racing team.
About how we could combine our open courseware with their design process.
So we ask them well which courses that are in your standard curriculum or are electives even did you use to design the car?
For the team manager, since he has 90 engineers, it was hard to answer this question, so we said I'll talk to all the different design teams.
There are four main design teams.
You can see it on the right.
There's a team for the chassis vehicle dynamics for the powertrain and for the electronics.
And we ask the teams to come up with a list of courses that they had followed at the University an after that applied in the design.

Of the car, so this also forced the students to reflect on their learning experience and how that related to the project work that they were doing at the time, which I think is also a very valuable experience for them.
We also managed to came to come up with a list of all these courses an hour students.
They have a minor in their third year.
That's a half year that they can spend on something that's not in our standard.
Reclam so by doing this we also had a list of courses that students could do in their minor so they could be of more use in the design project for the race car.
And the spin off from this project was, I think, maybe even bigger than from the Tamil project.
There were two courses that actually started using the design process of the students in the regular courses.
So we not only looked at which courses that we use, but we also engage with the teaching staff an we managed to come up with some new learning materials.
So what you see here is I have a couple of screenshots from an instructional video.
Elementary economics it's a course at our industrial design faculty.
At first sight, the link to race car design might not be so clear, but when we started talking we found out that it was very relevant and the teacher was very enthusiastic.
She actually contacted us 'cause she wanted to convert her course to.
Of course that was also available as a self study unit.
For Bachelor students that switch to industrial design, and she thought that this would be a really nice engaging case study.
So it starts with a picture of the car and it shows how the driver is positioned in the car which is.
There's a lot of regulations to that.
Anne it's a good case study 'cause from the case study with the car.
She could go through all the steps in a design process.
This is the car that we are talking about.
It shows the position of the driver in the car and this is the basis for the.
Further analysis of the position of the driver so there's different requirements 'cause the driver needs to get out of the car within a specific timeframe.
He still has to have the right overview.
All those things are in the case study now an she actually worked with the design team from the car to get it all into the case study properly.
So I think that's a really, really nice result.
And of course, race car aerodynamics also a very enthusiastic young teacher.
I think this is the course that maybe even fits the fits the topic best.
'cause it's.

It is really focused on race car design, so he is also in the process now of making new video lectures for his regular course on the basis of the experience that the students had with the race car design.
And that he has some standard models, but he's.
Also been working closely with the team.
To get the course ready for open courseware to have the case, study in there and they've been windtunnel testing together to and improve the car, and to get some.
New and innovative teaching materials for his course.

So I think the results for the tracing that it feeds back into the teaching is really important and really interesting, 'cause besides that, the fact that we could support the DOT Racing team besides the fact that we've expanded our open courseware offerings.
It also created spin off an it feeds back into the regular courses for our students.
For that racing we had six new courses.
We already had a couple of courses that apply to the team so that we could use.
As I said, the staff engagement was again really high 'cause we were producing new materials an everybody was enthusiastic about the project.
Adeline very well with the Dutch Dot Racing goal of sharing their knowledge and educating their engineers and a broader audience as well.
The students have to reflect on their learning experience in the regular courses and their learning experience in design competition.
And combine those an again we can link the theory from more courses to practice to a very tangible concrete design.
And it's also a recruitment tool for the racing team 'cause they need new engineers every year.
And now they can show them well if you take this course you can apply it in this way or in this design process.
While I also think that it's even a recruitment tool for perspective engineers 'cause.
Say you're a sixteen 1718 year old and you're into engineering.

Whether you like you like race cars, so you go through the dirt racing website, you check out their race cars and then you see, Oh well, these are all the interesting courses that I can follow at Delft University.
And then those courses which might be really basic and otherwise boring.
I can then apply to go and design A race car with my fellow students.
How am I on time?
10 minutes still OK.
So with these two case studies combined, I think we have a list of results.
Some of those are mainly in the internal processes of the University.
Some are external process is.
I have a short list here, so I think we managed to improve the education quality.
So what we usually see when we start publishing a course as open culture is that the quality improves automatically because it's going to be publicly available.

I think that has been the case for all the courses we have published, but on top of that because it combines so well with the staff engagement, they started even producing new learning materials so that even improve the quality of the education at our University more.
And those two case studies for the regular courses.
I also think that not just for the staff engagement but for the student engagement is very important 'cause they can.
They can show how the theory applies to practical design projects.
Well, we ask the students to reflect on their learning experience, so they were also very motivated to do so.
And for ourselves we had a really focused application of our open courses.
Where generally we published courses an don't really know where it will end.
For this we had a really good idea.
So for the design competition we knew that we were also going to send it through the course participants.
And that they could make use of them and that they could fill the gaps in the knowledge they had.
The knowledge needed for the design competition.

For about racing as well, we had a really clear audience and they've had a lot of feedback from other racing teams that are in the same design competition with them about the courses an since they were the first team to have a car with aerodynamics.
Also, the course on race car aerodynamics they think is going to be really valuable to their other competitors, so they said don't make it too good 'cause we still want to win it.
But it's also nice if they can learn from us 'cause that's one of our goals as a recruitment tool.
But I just discussed an for us as well.
It's it's a really nice and successful example of the possibilities of open courseware, where it can be applied.
And how can it help the project an even improve the project outcomes, improve the teaching.
So what we find is that it works really well to have a couple of those examples.
So once you start talking to people that they can immediately see, Oh well, I know this project that might benefit from a precursor as well so.
We hope to grow it from here.
Anne.
There are also some results externally.
With these two projects we I think also for Dutch Racing in particular, we managed to engage their wider audience.
Also, if you look at the visitors to our open courseware.
They were not in the hundreds of thousands, but we did see that the visitors that did come to the courses for that racing offer tammo.
They tend to hang around.
The course is a lot longer.
Next to Deptford outracing sorry.
Also they when they had the reveal, the design of the cars, they had a brake press moment at the market in Delft an we already on around those days we saw a spike in the number of visitors.
And also when they won the world record and were in all the newspapers we we had that same experience.
And for the wider audience, if they were people, not engineers or whatever, but just visiting the website, they could find some background information to do the project.
And recruitment tool already mentioned an we fulfilled and education demands.
So for example, the other teams that are not into aerodynamics yet.
Well, there's a demand there and we can fill it with our course.
Same goes for the sensor design competition.
There's a clear demand there an we can help out an publish some courses to fill that demand.
It also improved the project outcomes for both of the projects for the sensor design competition.
They were able to design A better sensor or better understand where it applies in hydrology.
Anne Anne for the racing theme.
One of their project goals is education and I think this has also improved that part of that project.
Next to that, we gain valuable feedback, especially from the sensor design competition.
For example, about the offline availability of our courses.
The level of our courses.
And what other improvements they would they would like to see?
You want questions?
Yes, OK good.
So the overall results, all of these things we reached while still expanding our open courseware.
Sharing our knowledge an showing what open courseware can do an really by doing a pretty basic thing.
Aligning our open courseware activities with some projects.
An aligning with their project goals and teaching activities.
Thank you.
Questions.
